definitionA: containing an apology or excuse for a fault, failure, insult, injury, etc.:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Having the character of apology; regretfully excusing
   2. Defending by words or arguments; said or written in defense.
etymology: First recorded in 1400–50; late Middle English apologetik “a formal defense,” from Middle French or directly from Late Latin apologēticus “written defense, defensive,” Greek apologētikós “fit for defense,” equivalent to apologē- (variant stem of apologeîsthai “to speak in defense”; apologia ) + -tikos -tic
example: Unidentified students interviewed afterwards told reporters that the comedian seemed not necessarily apologetic about the controversy he had stirred.

definitionA: to pay out (money), especially for expenses; expend.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To pay out, expend; usually from a public fund or treasury.
etymology: First recorded in 1520–30; from Middle French desbourser, Old French desborser, equivalent to des- dis- 1 + -borser, derivative of borse purse, from Late Latin bursa “bag”
example: It has already raised and disbursed several hundreds of thousands of dollars in grants to groups it has vetted.

definitionA: to free (a person) from deception or error.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To free (someone) of a misconception or misapprehension; to unveil a falsehood held by (somebody).
etymology: From the French word désabuser, dating back to 1605–15. See dis- 1, abuse
example: Nothing could be farther from the truth, and a closer look at data can help disabuse us of this notion.

definitionA: Also called  bear animalcule, water bear. any microscopic, chiefly herbivorous invertebrate of the phylum Tardigrada, living in water, on mosses, lichens, etc.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Sluggish; moving slowly.
<noun>
   1. A member of the animal phylum Tardigrada.
   2. Sloth.
etymology: First recorded in 1615–25, tardigrade is from the Latin word tardigradus slow-paced. See tardy, -grade
example: Likewise, space rocks flying around the solar system usually smash into planets and moons at thousands of meters per second — far too fast for tardigrades to survive.

definitionA: to move joltingly or roughly up and down; bounce.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The fourth derivative of the position vector with respect to time; the time derivative of jerk.
<verb>
   1. To jolt; to shake, especially by rough riding or by driving over obstructions.
etymology: 1400–50; late Middle English; apparently blend of joll to bump (now obsolete) and bounce
example: Harvey Cheyne's wife, she was sick back, an' we did n't want to jounce her.

definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A quality of endurance and courage.
   2. Good temperament and character.
   3. Metal; a metallic substance.
etymology: 1575–85; spelling variant of metal, in metaphoric usages
example: Bryson DeChambeau to test his long-driving mettle in professional event after Ryder CupJust after midnight on the Saturday before the Masters, Rahm’s wife, Kelley, gave birth to the couple’s first child, a son they named Kepa.

definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To make blissful.
   2. To pronounce or regard as happy, or supremely blessed, or as conferring happiness.
   3. To carry out the third of four steps in canonization, making someone a blessed.
etymology: First recorded in 1525–35; from Middle French beatifier, from Late Latin beātificāre; beatific ( def )
example: This tendency to beatify certain figures is something mainstream conservatives now share with extremist ideologies elsewhere.

definitionA: a skullcap worn by Orthodox Jewish males, also worn by most Conservative and some Reform Jewish males during prayer.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A skullcap worn by religious Jewish males (especially during prayer).
etymology: First recorded in 1845–50 as jarmolka; from Yiddish yarmlke, from Polish jarmułka, jamułka (earlier jałmurka, ) or Ukrainian yarmúlka, from Turkic; compare Turkish yağmurluk “rain gear,” equivalent to yağmur “rain” + -luk noun suffix; or from Medieval Latin almutia, armutia, aumucia, almucia “(furred) hood, hooded cape”; almuce ( def ), amice 2
example: That’s how he knows that of the 218 rabbis who delivered prayers in the “modern TV era,” 180 — 83 percent — wore yarmulkes.

definitionA: to deviate or wander away from the main topic or purpose in speaking or writing; depart from the principal line of argument, plot, study, etc.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To step or turn aside; to deviate; to swerve; especially, to turn aside from the main subject of attention, or course of argument, in writing or speaking.
   2. To turn aside from the right path; to transgress; to offend.
etymology: First recorded in 1520–30; from Latin dīgressus “departed,” past participle of dīgredī “to go off, depart, digress,” from dī- di- 2 + -gredī (combining form of gradī “to go”; grade )
example: Eszterhas describes how Gibson often would digress from the topic at hand to rant about Grigorieva.

definitionA: walking on the whole sole of the foot, as humans and bears.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A plantigrade animal; an animal that walks with the entire sole of the foot on the ground.
<adjective>
   1. Of an animal: walking with the entire sole of the foot on the ground.
etymology: First recorded in 1825–35; from French plantigrade (noun), from New Latin plantigradus, equivalent to Latin plant(a) “sole of the foot” + -i- + -gradus; -i-, -grade
example: In considering this question, the first fact to appear is that the apes and lemurs are plantigrade animals.

definitionA: walking on the toes, as most quadruped mammals.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. (chiefly in the plural) A digitigrade animal; an animal that walks on its toes, such as a cat or a dog.
<adjective>
   1. Of an animal: walking on the toes, putting the weight of the body mainly on the ball of the foot, with the back of the foot, or heel, raised.
   2. Of feet or a manner of walking: of, resembling, or pertaining to that of a digitigrade animal.
   3. (specifically) Belonging to the Digitigrada of the taxonomic order Carnivora.
etymology: From French, dating back to 1825–35; digiti-, -grade
example: It is digitigrade: it has five toes on the fore, and four toes on its hinder feet; its marsupial bones are simply rudimental.
